title: Calvin Klein Parent PVH Is Slumping, but CEO Manny Chirico Bought Up Stock
text:
Text size

Shares of apparel company PVH , owner of brands including Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger, have been losing their shirt, but Chairman and CEO Emanuel “Manny” Chirico has been buying up stock.

PVH stock (ticker: PVH) crumbled 32.3% in 2018, and through Friday’s close it has lost an additional 8.1% this year. The S&P 500, by comparison, slipped only 7.2% in 2018, and this year sports a 18.8% gain.

In July, Goldman Sachs downgraded PVH stock to Sell from Neutral, citing challenges for the Calvin Klein brand and slowing growth at Tommy Hilfiger.

On Aug. 15, PVH stock slipped to an intraday low of $67.41; shares haven’t traded at that level since January 2016.

On Aug. 28, PVH reported a stronger-than-expected second quarter but lowered its forecasts. Credit Suisse said PVH “did the right thing” by lowering guidance in the face of an “increasingly volatile macro.” Analyst Michael Binetti reiterated an Outperform rating and raised the target price to $105 from $97.

CEO Chirico bought more PVH stock days after the second-quarter report, paying $10 million on Sept. 3 for 133,155 shares, an average per-share price of $74.99. He now owns 417,351 shares in a personal account, including 46,694 shares subject to awards of restricted stock units, and 9,427 more shares through a 401(k) account, according to a form Chirico filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Chirico’s purchase is the largest in terms of value and share volume since at least 2002, according to S&P Capital IQ.

In a statement provided via email to Barron’s, Chirico said, “My purchase of PVH stock underscores my strong conviction in the underlying value of our stock, which the financial markets are not currently reflecting. Specifically, I believe the power of PVH’s diversified business model, the strength of our brands and the various growth opportunities present a compelling proposition. With our two greatest assets—our brands and our people—I have great confidence that PVH is well-positioned to deliver a long-term, sustainable trajectory of growth for our stockholders.”

It is the CEO’s first open-market purchase of PVH stock this year. Chirico last bought shares on Dec. 14, 2018, when he paid $955,000 for 10,000 PVH shares, an average per-share price of $95.51.

Inside Scoop is a regular Barron’s feature covering stock transactions by corporate executives and board members—so-called insiders—as well as large shareholders, politicians, and other prominent figures. Due to their insider status, these investors are required to disclose stock trades with the Securities and Exchange Commission or other regulatory groups.

description: PVH stock traded to a multiyear low in August, but Chirico paid $10 million for more shares. The CEO told Barron’s he has “strong conviction in the underlying value of our stock.”
